title: EAC Climate Change Policy
description: The East African Community Climate Change Policy (2011) outlines a regional framework for addressing the adverse impacts of climate change across Burundi, Kenya, Rwanda, Tanzania, and Uganda. Developed in response to directives from EAC Heads of State, the policy promotes coordinated adaptation, mitigation, and research efforts to safeguard socio-economic development. It emphasizes urgent action on food security, disaster risk reduction, ecosystem protection, and low-carbon development, while integrating gender equity and leveraging international mechanisms like the UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol. The policy also calls for national and regional institutional frameworks, capacity building, and the establishment of an EAC Climate Change Fund to support implementation.

title: EAC Climate Change Master Plan(20111-2031)
description: The East African Community (EAC) Climate Change Master Plan (2011–2031)** provides a long-term regional framework to address climate risks across the EAC member countries. Developed through a consultative process, it outlines strategies for adaptation, mitigation, research, and capacity building to safeguard socio-economic development. The plan emphasizes food security, disaster risk reduction, ecosystem protection, and low-carbon growth, while promoting gender equity and alignment with international agreements such as the UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol. It also calls for establishing an EAC Climate Change Fund to support coordinated implementation and resilience-building efforts.

title: EAC Heads of State Retreat on Food Security and Climate Change
description: he EAC Heads of State Retreat on Food Security and Climate Change brought together leaders from the East African Community to deliberate on urgent regional challenges posed by climate change and its impact on food systems. The retreat underscored the need for coordinated adaptation and mitigation strategies, emphasizing sustainable agriculture, water resource management, and disaster risk reduction. Leaders highlighted the importance of regional cooperation, institutional capacity building, and mobilization of climate finance to safeguard livelihoods and accelerate resilience. The retreat also reaffirmed commitments to align national actions with global frameworks such as the UNFCCC and the SDGs, while promoting inclusive participation of women, youth, and vulnerable communities.

title: Technical Assessment of Climate Finance in the EAC
source: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC)
description: The Technical Assessment of Climate Finance in the East African Community (EAC), prepared under the UNFCCC Needs-based Climate Finance project, provides a detailed analysis of climate finance flows, needs, and barriers across Burundi, Kenya, Rwanda, South Sudan, Tanzania, and Uganda. Covering 2013–2018, the report notes that the region received about USD 15 billion in public climate finance, far below the estimated USD 198–853 billion needed by 2030 for adaptation and mitigation.

title: Rwanda National Environment and Climate Change Policy
description: The Rwanda National Environment and Climate Change Policy (2019) provides a unified framework for sustainable development, environmental protection, and climate resilience. It promotes green growth, low-carbon development, and ecosystem conservation while integrating climate adaptation and mitigation across sectors. The policy emphasizes inclusive governance, capacity building, and mobilization of green finance, aligning national efforts with global commitments like the Paris Agreement and the SDGs. It guides implementation through district and sectoral plans, aiming to improve livelihoods, reduce vulnerability, and ensure a clean, healthy environment for current and future generations.

title: Rwanda’s Climate Adaptation Monitoring, Evaluation, and Learning System in the Agriculture Sector:  Aims, objectives, and needs
description:
Rwanda’s Climate Adaptation Monitoring, Evaluation, and Learning (MEL) System in the Agriculture Sector aims to track, assess, and improve climate adaptation efforts through data-driven decision-making and inclusive governance.
The MEL system supports Rwanda’s updated Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) by identifying relevant indicators, evaluating adaptation impacts, and promoting learning to inform future policies. It emphasizes institutional coordination, timely data collection, and integration with national planning tools like the Environment and Natural Resources Management Information System (ENR MIS). The system also prioritizes gender equity, stakeholder engagement, and alignment with international frameworks such as the Paris Agreement.

title: Rwanda Snapshot on Water and Climate
description:
The Rwanda Snapshot on Water and Climate provides a concise overview of the country’s water resources, climate risks, and resilience strategies, highlighting progress and challenges in achieving SDG 6 and climate adaptation goals.
Rwanda’s hydrographic system is divided between the Nile and Congo basins, with 90% of surface water draining into the Nile. Despite abundant springs and wetlands, access to improved water services remains limited, especially in rural areas. Climate risks—such as floods, landslides, and erosion—pose serious threats to infrastructure, agriculture, and livelihoods. The snapshot underscores high water quality risks, low drought risk, and extremely high flood vulnerability. It also tracks Rwanda’s progress in sanitation coverage, integrated water resource management, and gender-inclusive governance. Institutional reforms, increased WASH financing, and alignment with national strategies like Vision 2050 and the Green Growth and Climate Resilience Strategy are key to enhancing water security and climate resilience.

title: Situational Analysis: Low Carbon and Climate Resilient Agricultural actions in Rwanda
source: Rwanda Ministry of Agriculture and Animal Resources
description:
This situational analysis outlines Rwanda’s strategic priorities for transitioning to low-carbon and climate-resilient agriculture, identifying key gaps, cost-effective interventions, and alignment with national and international climate goals.
The report, developed by Rwanda’s Ministry of Agriculture with UNDP support, assesses the agriculture sector’s role in achieving the country’s updated Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC). Agriculture accounts for over 50% of Rwanda’s emissions and NDC costs, making it central to climate action. The analysis highlights adaptation measures such as climate-resilient crops, irrigation expansion, agroforestry, and insurance schemes, alongside mitigation actions like improved livestock husbandry, manure management, and energy-efficient agro-processing. It identifies gaps in policy alignment, financing, and data systems, and recommends integrating mitigation and adaptation in future sector plans to ensure sustainable, inclusive, and climate-smart agricultural development.

title: RWANDA ENERGY POLICY
description: The Rwanda Energy Policy (2015) sets out a comprehensive framework to ensure reliable, affordable, and sustainable energy access for households, businesses, and industries. It emphasizes expanding electricity generation and access, reducing dependence on biomass, promoting clean cooking fuels, and diversifying energy sources such as hydropower, solar, methane gas, geothermal, and petroleum. The policy also prioritizes energy efficiency, demand-side management, and private sector participation to drive investment and innovation. By aligning with Rwanda’s Vision 2020 and EDPRS-II, the policy positions energy as a key enabler of socio-economic transformation, poverty reduction, and climate resilience.

title:
Renewable energy investment factsheet: 
Rwanda
source: Accelerated Partnership for Renewables in Africa (APRA)
description:
The APRE Renewable Energy Investment Factsheet: Rwanda (2023) provides a concise overview of Rwanda’s energy transition goals, investment opportunities, and policy incentives. It highlights the country’s ambition to achieve universal electrification by 2024 and increase the share of renewable energy to 60% by 2030, while reducing reliance on biomass for cooking.
This factsheet positions Rwanda as an emerging regional energy hub, leveraging renewables to drive sustainable growth, reduce emissions, and attract private sector investment.

title: RWANDA ENERGY PROFILE
description:
The IRENA Renewable Energy Investment Factsheet: Rwanda (2025) provides a statistical overview of Rwanda’s energy mix, renewable potential, and policy framework. It shows that renewables account for over half of Rwanda’s electricity generation (53% in 2022), primarily from hydropower, with solar and bioenergy contributing smaller shares.
This factsheet positions Rwanda as a country with strong renewable potential, where hydropower remains dominant but solar and clean cooking solutions are critical for diversifying energy access and achieving climate goals.

title:
RWANDA RENEWABLE 
ENERGY FUND PROJECT
description: The Rwanda Renewable Energy Fund (REF) Project is the country’s largest off-grid electrification initiative, launched in 2017 with support from the Climate Investment Funds (SREP) and the World Bank. Implemented through the Development Bank of Rwanda, the project provides credit lines and subsidies to expand solar home systems and mini-grids, targeting rural households and small businesses. By engaging the private sector, REF aims to overcome barriers such as affordability, limited financing, and regulatory challenges. The project strengthens energy access, supports climate resilience, and contributes to Rwanda’s goal of universal electrification by 2024.

title:
HYDRO, SOLAR, AND WIND: ENERGY POLICY 
IMPLICATION IN RENEWABLE ENERGY DEPLOYMENT IN 
RWANDA
description: This paper examines Rwanda’s renewable energy sector, focusing on hydro, solar, and wind resources and their policy implications. Conducted at the Pan African University Institute of Water and Energy Sciences (2017), the study analyzes meteorological data from five locations to assess solar and wind potential, while reviewing Rwanda’s energy policy and strategic plans. Findings show hydro dominates electricity generation (60% of installed capacity), yet solar radiation is strong nationwide and wind potential exists in Kanombe. The paper concludes that Rwanda’s energy policy overly favors hydro, urging diversification and stronger promotion of solar and wind to ensure sustainable, climate-resilient energy development.

title: Draft ENERGY SECTOR STRATEGIC PLAN
description:
The Draft Energy Sector Strategic Plan (2018–2023) provides Rwanda’s roadmap for achieving universal energy access, strengthening reliability, and transitioning to sustainable energy systems. It sets ambitious targets to expand electricity generation, diversify energy sources, reduce transmission losses, and promote modern cooking technologies, while ensuring petroleum reserves cover three months of supply.
This plan positions energy as a critical enabler of Rwanda’s economic transformation, supporting industrialization, urbanization, and poverty reduction while ensuring sustainability and resilience.

title:
Rwanda: Energy 
Development Plan to 
Decarbonise the Economy
source:
The University of Technology Sydney  
Institute for Sustainable Futures
description: This report titled “Rwanda: Energy Development Plan to Decarbonise the Economy” (2025) by the University of Technology Sydney’s Institute for Sustainable Futures outlines pathways for Rwanda to achieve a fully decarbonised energy system by 2050. It emphasizes scaling up solar power, electrifying cooking and transport, and improving energy efficiency to meet Paris Agreement targets. The plan highlights investment needs, socio-economic benefits, and community participation, positioning Rwanda as a leader in Africa’s clean energy transition.

title: Kenya National Climate Change Framework Policy
source: Kenya Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources
description: Kenya’s National Climate Change Framework Policy (2016) establishes a comprehensive approach to climate resilience and low-carbon development. It integrates climate change into national and county planning, aligning with Vision 2030 and international commitments like the UNFCCC. The policy prioritizes adaptation in vulnerable sectors—agriculture, water, health—and promotes mitigation through renewable energy, reforestation, and sustainable transport. It emphasizes inclusive governance, public awareness, and equitable participation, including gender and youth. Through institutional coordination and stakeholder engagement, the policy aims to safeguard livelihoods, ecosystems, and economic growth against climate risks.

title: Policy Brief Climate Security in Kenya
description:
This brief highlights how climate change acts as a threat multiplier, intensifying existing vulnerabilities such as poverty, resource scarcity, and political instability—especially in Kenya’s arid and semi-arid regions. It emphasizes that traditional security approaches are insufficient to address climate-induced risks like migration, food insecurity, and intercommunal conflict.
Key recommendations include strengthening early warning systems, integrating climate data into security planning, and supporting community-based resilience strategies. The brief urges Kenya to lead in shaping global discourse on climate security, especially within the African Union and UN frameworks.

title: Climate Resilience and Water Security: Key Messages from the REACH Kenya Programme (2015-2024)
description:
The REACH Kenya Programme (2015–2024) highlights the critical role of climate-resilient water services in reducing poverty and vulnerability in arid and semi-arid regions.
This report synthesizes key lessons from nearly a decade of research and action across Turkana, Kitui, and Nairobi. It emphasizes that climate resilience in water security requires long-term investment, inclusive governance, and adaptive infrastructure. The programme demonstrates how reliable water access improves health, education, and livelihoods, especially for women and marginalized groups. It calls for integrating climate risk into water planning, strengthening monitoring systems, and supporting county-level institutions. The findings advocate for scaling evidence-based, locally led solutions to build resilience in the face of growing climate pressures.

title: KENYA CLIMATE SMART AGRICULTURE STRATEGY (2017 - 2026)
description:
Kenya’s Climate Smart Agriculture Strategy (2017–2026) provides a national framework to enhance agricultural productivity, build climate resilience, and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
The strategy outlines four key pillars: adaptation and resilience, mitigation of emissions, enabling policy and institutional frameworks, and addressing cross-cutting issues such as financing, gender inclusion, and capacity building. It targets vulnerable farming systems—especially rain-fed agriculture—by promoting sustainable land and water management, climate-resilient crops, and efficient livestock practices. With an estimated investment need of KSh 500 billion, the strategy aligns with Vision 2030 and Kenya’s international climate commitments, aiming to transform agriculture into a climate-smart, inclusive, and economically viable sector.

title: Agriculture and Climate Change in Kenya: Climate Chaos, Policy Dilemmas
source: Immaculate Mainai, Andrew Newshamii and Michael Okotii
description:
This paper explores how climate change is reshaping Kenya’s agricultural policy landscape, revealing tensions between technical solutions, competing interests, and the realities of smallholder farming.
Authored by Maina, Newsham, and Okoti, the study maps key narratives—such as food security, resilience, and climate-smart agriculture—and examines how actors from government, NGOs, and the private sector position themselves within these debates. It highlights policy fragmentation, limited farmer engagement, and the dominance of top-down approaches. The authors call for more inclusive, coherent, and locally grounded strategies to ensure climate responses truly support vulnerable communities and sustainable agricultural development.

title: An Assessment of Agricultural Sector Policies and Climate Change in Kenya: Nexus between Research and Practice
source: Wilfred Nyangena, Paul Guthiga, Maurice Ogada, Geophrey Sikei
description:
This paper assesses the alignment between agricultural policies and climate change responses in Kenya, highlighting gaps between research insights and policy implementation.
Authored by Nyangena, Guthiga, Ogada, and Sikei, the study examines how climate change is addressed in key agricultural strategies and whether evidence from research informs policy decisions. It finds limited integration of climate risks into planning, weak institutional coordination, and inadequate use of scientific data. The authors advocate for stronger linkages between research and policymaking, improved stakeholder engagement, and climate-responsive agricultural reforms to enhance resilience and sustainability.

title: Kenya National Energy Policy 2025 – 2034 (Draft 1)
description: Kenya National Energy Policy 2025–2034 provides a strategic framework to guide the country’s energy transition over the next decade. It emphasizes universal access, affordability, and energy security, while promoting renewable energy sources such as solar, wind, geothermal, and bioenergy. The policy seeks to reduce dependence on fossil fuels, expand clean cooking solutions, and drive green industrialization. It also highlights innovation, resilience, and sustainability as key pillars, ensuring equitable participation of communities and private sector actors in shaping Kenya’s energy future.

title: Kenya 2024: Energy Policy Review
description: The IEA Kenya 2024: Energy Policy Review provides a comprehensive assessment of Kenya’s energy sector, highlighting progress, challenges, and pathways for sustainable growth. The report notes Kenya’s strong reliance on renewable energy, with geothermal, hydropower, wind, and solar contributing over 80% of electricity generation. It emphasizes the country’s ambition to achieve universal access by 2030, expand clean cooking solutions, and strengthen energy security through regional power trade and infrastructure investment. The review also underscores the importance of private sector participation, regulatory reforms, and climate resilience in driving Kenya’s transition to a low-carbon economy.

title: Kenya National Energy Efficiency and Conservation Strategy
description: The Kenya National Energy Efficiency and Conservation Strategy (2020) provides a framework to reduce energy intensity and promote sustainable consumption across all sectors of the economy. It sets targets to improve efficiency in industry, transport, buildings, and appliances, while expanding clean cooking solutions and reducing reliance on biomass. The strategy emphasizes regulatory reforms, awareness campaigns, and incentives to drive private sector participation. By aligning with Kenya’s Vision 2030 and climate commitments, it aims to cut greenhouse gas emissions, lower energy costs, and enhance competitiveness, positioning efficiency as a key pillar of Kenya’s green growth agenda.

title: KENYA ENERGY PROFILE
description: The IRENA Kenya Energy Profile (2025) highlights the country’s strong reliance on renewable energy and its leadership in clean power generation in Africa. In 2022, over 80% of electricity generation came from renewables, primarily geothermal, hydropower, wind, and solar. While modern renewables dominate electricity supply, traditional biomass remains significant in household energy use. The profile underscores Kenya’s progress toward universal access, yet notes challenges in expanding clean cooking and reducing dependence on biomass. With abundant geothermal and solar potential, Kenya is positioned to strengthen energy security, resilience, and sustainable development.

title: TANZANIA NATIONAL CLIMATE CHANGE RESPONSE STRATEGY 2021-2026
description: Tanzania’s National Climate Change Response Strategy (2021–2026) provides a comprehensive roadmap for enhancing climate resilience and pursuing low-emission development. It aims to mainstream climate action across national and local plans, aligning with Vision 2025 and global commitments like the Paris Agreement. The strategy prioritizes adaptation in key sectors—agriculture, water, health, energy, and infrastructure—while promoting mitigation through renewable energy, sustainable land use, and forest conservation. It also emphasizes cross-cutting issues such as climate finance, capacity building, gender inclusion, and public-private partnerships to ensure inclusive, sustainable, and climate-smart development.

title: Climate-Smart Agriculture in Tanzania
description:
Tanzania’s Climate-Smart Agriculture (CSA) profile (May 2017) outlines strategies to enhance agricultural productivity, resilience, and sustainability under changing climate conditions.
The report highlights viable CSA practices such as agroforestry, conservation agriculture, improved livestock management, and water harvesting. It emphasizes the need for site-specific approaches, stronger extension services, and better access to finance and markets. With agriculture contributing significantly to GDP and employing over half the population, CSA is positioned as a key pathway to reduce climate risks, improve food security, and support low-emission development. Institutional coordination and public-private partnerships are critical for scaling CSA nationwide.

title: Tazania Agriculture Climate Resilience Plan 2014-2019
description:
Tanzania’s Agriculture Climate Resilience Plan (2014–2019) outlines strategic actions to safeguard agricultural productivity against climate risks and build long-term resilience.
The plan focuses on climate-smart practices, sustainable land and water management, early warning systems, and institutional capacity building. It targets vulnerable farming communities and promotes integration of climate adaptation into national and local agricultural policies. Key priorities include improving research and extension services, enhancing access to climate information, and mobilizing resources for implementation. The plan aligns with Tanzania’s broader development goals and international climate commitments, aiming to reduce vulnerability and support food security under changing climate conditions.

title: Climate Change Impacts on Water Quality in Tanzania: A Comprehensive Review for Sustainable Water Resource Management
source: Catherine Salim, Ghanima Chanzi, Neema Mpayo
description:
This research paper provides a comprehensive review of how climate change is affecting water quality in Tanzania, with implications for sustainable water resource management.
Authored by Catherine Salim, Ghanima Chanzi, and Neema Mpayo, the study examines the links between rising temperatures, erratic rainfall, and increased pollution in surface and groundwater systems. It highlights key challenges such as eutrophication, salinization, and microbial contamination, particularly in urban and agricultural zones. The authors emphasize the need for integrated water resource management, improved monitoring systems, and climate-resilient infrastructure to safeguard public health and ecosystem services in the face of growing climate pressures.

title: Tanzania Snapshot on  Water and Climate
description:
The Tanzania Snapshot on Water and Climate provides a concise overview of the country’s water resources, climate vulnerabilities, and policy responses.
Tanzania faces increasing climate risks, including floods, droughts, and water scarcity, which threaten agriculture, health, and livelihoods. The snapshot highlights high water quality risks, moderate flood and drought risks, and limited access to improved water and sanitation services, especially in rural areas. It emphasizes the need for integrated water resource management, climate-resilient infrastructure, and stronger institutional coordination. The document also tracks progress toward SDG 6 and underscores the importance of gender equity, financing, and data systems in building water and climate resilience.

title: TANZANIA COUNTRY CLIMATE AND DEVELOPMENT REPORT
description: The Tanzania Country Climate and Development Report (2024) by the World Bank outlines how climate change threatens Tanzania’s growth, especially in agriculture, urban infrastructure, and natural resource management. It recommends climate-smart agriculture, resilient urban planning, clean energy, and improved water governance to reduce vulnerability and unlock green economic opportunities. With rising climate risks and rapid urbanization, the report urges integrated planning, targeted investments, and inclusive policies to support sustainable development and poverty reduction.

title: Tanzania National Energy Policy
source: Tanzania Ministry of Energy and Minerals
description: The Tanzania National Energy Policy (2015) sets out a framework to ensure reliable, affordable, and sustainable energy services while driving socio-economic growth. It emphasizes diversification of energy sources, including natural gas, coal, hydro, solar, wind, and biomass, alongside rural electrification and private sector participation. The policy promotes energy efficiency, clean cooking alternatives, and environmental safeguards, while strengthening governance and regulatory institutions. By targeting electricity, petroleum, gas, and renewables, the policy positions Tanzania to harness its abundant resources for energy security, sustainability, and inclusive development.

title:
POLICY ROADMAP FOR 100% RENEWABLE ENERGY  
AND POVERTY ERADICATION  
IN TANZANIA
description: The Policy Roadmap for 100% Renewable Energy and Poverty Eradication in Tanzania (2017), developed by the World Future Council and partners, outlines a vision for universal energy access through a complete transition to renewables. It emphasizes decentralized solutions like solar home systems and mini-grids to reduce reliance on biomass and fossil fuels. The roadmap highlights socio-economic benefits including poverty reduction, job creation, and gender equity, while calling for stronger financing, policy frameworks, and community participation.

title: TANZANIA ENERGY PROFILE
description: The IRENA Tanzania Energy Profile (2025) outlines the country’s energy mix, highlighting its strong reliance on renewables and traditional biomass. In 2022, renewables contributed 78% of total electricity generation, mainly from hydropower, while solar and wind remain underutilized despite significant potential. Biomass continues to dominate household energy use, underscoring challenges in clean cooking and energy efficiency. The profile emphasizes Tanzania’s progress in expanding electricity access, yet notes persistent rural gaps. Diversification into modern renewables is seen as key to strengthening energy security, resilience, and sustainable development.

title: Burundi National Adaptation Programmes of Action to Climate Change
source: Burundi Ministry for Land Management, Tourism and Environment
description:
The National Adaptation Programme of Action (NAPA) for Burundi (2007) outlines the country’s urgent priorities for adapting to climate change impacts. Prepared by the Ministry for Land Management, Tourism and Environment with UNDP and GEF support, the plan identifies Burundi’s acute vulnerability to droughts, floods, soil erosion, and biodiversity loss, which threaten agriculture, water resources, energy, health, and natural ecosystems.
The NAPA emphasizes community-based adaptation, reforestation, erosion control, rainwater harvesting, climate-resilient crops, and renewable energy as immediate priorities. It also highlights the importance of early warning systems, institutional capacity building, and integration of climate resilience into national development strategies. Twelve priority projects were formulated to reduce vulnerability, safeguard livelihoods, and strengthen resilience, aligning with Burundi’s commitments under the UNFCCC and Kyoto Protocol.

title: WATER SECTOR AND CLIMATE RESILIENCE BUILDING SUPPORT PROGRAMME IN BURUNDI (PASEREC - PHASE 1)
description: The Burundi Water Sector and Climate Resilience Building Support Programme (PASEREC Phase 1) aims to enhance access to safe water and strengthen climate resilience in vulnerable communities. Supported by the African Development Bank, it focuses on rehabilitating water infrastructure, promoting integrated watershed management, and building institutional capacity for climate risk planning. The program emphasizes inclusive participation, especially of women and youth, and supports climate-smart agriculture and disaster preparedness. It aligns with Burundi’s national development goals and contributes to regional and global climate commitments.

title: BURUNDI THIRD NATIONAL COMMUNICATION ON CLIMATE CHANGE (TNCCC)/EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
description:
Burundi’s Third National Communication on Climate Change (2019) outlines the country’s climate vulnerabilities, greenhouse gas emissions trends, and strategic adaptation and mitigation measures across key sectors.
The report highlights agriculture, energy, water resources, health, and infrastructure as the most climate-sensitive areas. Between 2005 and 2015, emissions rose due to deforestation and land conversion, with the agriculture and energy sectors as major contributors. Despite being a net carbon sink, Burundi’s sequestration capacity is declining. The document presents sector-specific adaptation strategies—such as conservation agriculture, improved livestock systems, renewable energy, and resilient infrastructure—and calls for enhanced public awareness, institutional coordination, and technology transfer to support climate-resilient development.

title: BURUNDI: NATIONAL CLIMATE CHANGE PROFILE
description:
Burundi’s National Climate Change Profile highlights the country’s acute vulnerability to climate risks, especially in agriculture, water resources, and public health.
The profile outlines rising temperatures, erratic rainfall, and increased frequency of floods and droughts, which threaten food security and rural livelihoods. It emphasizes limited adaptive capacity, high dependence on rain-fed farming, and weak institutional coordination. Key priorities include integrating climate resilience into national planning, strengthening early warning systems, and mobilizing climate finance. The document also stresses the importance of community-based adaptation, gender inclusion, and regional cooperation to address transboundary climate challenges.

title: BURUNDI ENERGY PROFILE
description: The IRENA Burundi Energy Profile (2025) highlights the country’s heavy reliance on renewable energy, with 82% of total supply in 2022 coming mainly from bioenergy and hydropower. Electricity generation remains modest at 405 GWh, of which 96% is renewable, dominated by hydro. Despite abundant solar potential, uptake is limited, while biomass continues to dominate household energy use. The profile underscores challenges in energy self-sufficiency (down to 81%) and the need for diversification into solar and wind.

title: Energy Strategy and Action Plan for Burundi
description: The Burundi Energy Strategy and Action Plan (2011) sets out a roadmap to expand modern energy access, diversify sources, and strengthen sustainability. It prioritizes hydropower development, rural electrification, and promotion of solar, biomass, and peat as alternatives to traditional fuels. The plan also emphasizes energy efficiency, private sector participation, and institutional reforms to improve governance. By linking energy access to poverty reduction, gender equity, and climate resilience, the strategy positions Burundi’s energy sector as a driver of inclusive socio-economic growth.

title: Uganda National Climate Change Policy
source: Uganda Ministry of Water and Environment
description: Uganda’s National Climate Change Policy (2015) provides a strategic framework for coordinated climate action across sectors and governance levels. It aims to ensure climate resilience, promote low-carbon development, and integrate climate change into national planning and budgeting processes. The policy prioritizes adaptation in agriculture, water, health, and infrastructure, while supporting mitigation through renewable energy, sustainable forestry, and efficient transport. It emphasizes institutional capacity building, public awareness, and stakeholder engagement, including gender and youth inclusion. Implementation is led by the Climate Change Department under the Ministry of Water and Environment, aligning with Uganda’s Vision 2040 and global commitments like the UNFCCC and SDGs.

title: Uganda Snapshot on Water and Climate
description:
Uganda’s Snapshot on Water and Climate highlights growing challenges in water access, sanitation, and climate resilience amid rapid population growth and environmental degradation.
Despite low overall water stress, Uganda faces extremely high risks in water quality, sanitation, and regulatory capacity. Wetland loss, urban migration, and underinvestment threaten service delivery, with projections showing that 90% of Ugandans may lack safely managed water by 2030. Climate change is intensifying floods, droughts, and displacement, while governance gaps and limited gender inclusion hinder adaptive capacity. The snapshot calls for urgent reforms in financing, data systems, and transboundary water management to safeguard livelihoods and meet SDG 6 targets.

title: UGANDA NATIONAL CLIMATE CHANGE ACT
description:
Uganda’s National Climate Change Act (2021) establishes a legal framework for coordinated climate action, aligning national efforts with global agreements like the Paris Accord and supporting climate-resilient development.
The Act provides for monitoring, reporting, and verification of climate impacts, institutional coordination, and financing mechanisms. It mandates the creation of District Climate Change Action Plans, empowers local governments to develop ordinances, and ensures representation of smallholder farmers and women in advisory committees. Key provisions include support for climate-smart agriculture, public awareness, and access to grants and incentives for climate innovations. The Act also enables litigation for climate-related harm and requires climate responsiveness in national budgeting. It is spearheaded by the Ministry of Water and Environment and the Ministry of Agriculture, Animal Industry and Fisheries.

title:
Climate Change and Future 
Crop Suitability in Uganda
source: Hunter. R., Crespo. O., Coldrey, K, Cronin, K, New, M.
description:
This paper assesses how climate change will affect the future suitability of key crops in Uganda, offering region-specific insights to guide adaptation planning for smallholder farmers.
Authored by Hunter, Crespo, Coldrey, Cronin, and New, the study was produced by the University of Cape Town for IFAD’s Adaptation for Smallholder Agriculture Programme (ASAP). It uses climate projections and the EcoCrop model to evaluate how rising temperatures and shifting rainfall patterns will impact crops like beans, cassava, maize, groundnuts, sesame, and soybeans across Uganda’s four regions.

title:
UGANDA CLIMATE SMART
 AGRICULTURE
description:
Uganda’s Climate Smart Agriculture (CSA) Guide (2021) offers a practical roadmap for scaling resilient, low-emission farming across the country’s diverse agro ecological zones.
Developed by the Ministry of Agriculture with support from CARE, Oxfam, CRS, and World Vision, the guide documents CSA practices such as intercropping, agroforestry, water harvesting, conservation agriculture, and climate-resilient livestock systems. It highlights case studies from districts like Sheema, Mbarara, and Mukono, showing how farmers are adapting to droughts, floods, and soil degradation. The guide also maps CSA stakeholders, outlines enabling policies, and promotes farmer-to-farmer learning to accelerate adoption. It aligns with Uganda’s National Climate Change Policy and aims to reach 6 million farming households with climate-smart solutions.

title: ENERGY POLICY FOR UGANDA
source: Uganda Ministry of Energy and Mineral Development
description: The Energy Policy for Uganda (2023) provides a comprehensive framework to guide the country’s energy transition toward sustainability, security, and universal access. It emphasizes diversification of energy sources, with strong focus on renewables such as hydropower, solar, wind, and biomass, while reducing reliance on fossil fuels. The policy prioritizes rural electrification, clean cooking solutions, and energy efficiency to improve livelihoods and reduce environmental impacts. It also strengthens governance, private sector participation, and regional power trade, positioning Uganda to achieve inclusive growth, climate resilience, and its long-term development goals.

title: UGANDA ENERGY PROFILE
description: The IRENA Uganda Energy Profile (2025) provides an overview of the country’s energy mix, emphasizing its strong reliance on renewables and traditional biomass. In 2022, renewables contributed 92% of electricity generation, primarily from hydropower, while solar and wind remain underutilized despite significant potential. Biomass continues to dominate household energy use, underscoring challenges in clean cooking and energy efficiency. The profile highlights Uganda’s progress in expanding electricity access, yet notes persistent rural gaps. Diversification into modern renewables is seen as key to strengthening energy security, resilience, and sustainable development.

title: South Sudan National Adaptation Plan for Climate Change
source: South Sudan Ministry of Environment and Forestry
description: South Sudan’s National Adaptation Plan (NAP) identifies priority actions to address the country’s high vulnerability to climate change, particularly in agriculture, water, health, and disaster risk management. Developed with support from UNDP, the plan emphasizes institutional strengthening, climate data systems, and community-based adaptation. It promotes sustainable land use, early warning systems, and resilient infrastructure, while integrating gender equity and conflict sensitivity. The NAP aligns with South Sudan’s development goals and international commitments under the UNFCCC, aiming to reduce climate risks and enhance adaptive capacity across all sectors.

title: Rising from the Depths Water Security and Fragility in South Sudan
description:
This World Bank report explores how water insecurity and climate change deepen fragility in South Sudan, while also offering pathways for resilience and recovery.
Titled “Rising from the Depths: Water Security and Fragility in South Sudan”, the 2023 report highlights the country’s extreme vulnerability to floods, droughts, and displacement. It documents how three consecutive years of severe flooding (2019–2021) affected over a million people and caused economic losses exceeding $670 million, exacerbated by weak institutions and decades of conflict.
By harnessing its vast water resources—especially the Nile Basin and Sudd wetlands—South Sudan can turn water from a source of fragility into a foundation for peace and development.

title: Rapid Situation Assessment and Gap Analysis Report in South Sudan
description: The Rapid Situation Assessment and Gap Analysis Report in South Sudan (SEforALL, 2013) provides a detailed overview of the country’s energy access challenges and opportunities. It highlights South Sudan’s extreme energy poverty, with less than 1% of the population connected to the grid and heavy reliance on traditional biomass for cooking. The report identifies gaps in policy, financing, and infrastructure, while emphasizing the potential of decentralized renewable energy solutions such as solar home systems and mini-grids. It calls for stronger institutional frameworks, private sector engagement, and targeted investment to accelerate universal access and support climate resilience.

title:
The Geopolitics Of Energy Resources In South Sudan: 
Examining The Geopolitical Implications Of Oil, Gas, And 
Renewable Energy, Including The Impact Of Resource 
Dependence, Energy Security, And Energy Access 
Competition
description: This research paper explores how oil, gas, and renewable energy shape the country’s political economy and regional relations. It examines the implications of resource dependence, energy security challenges, and competition over energy access. The study highlights South Sudan’s reliance on oil revenues, vulnerability to global price fluctuations, and the geopolitical tensions with neighboring states over pipelines and trade. It also considers renewable energy as a potential pathway to diversify the energy mix, reduce conflict drivers, and strengthen long-term stability.

title: SOUTH SUDAN ENERGY PROFILE
description: The IRENA South Sudan Energy Profile (2025) provides an overview of the country’s energy mix, highlighting its reliance on traditional biomass and limited electricity generation. In 2022, renewables accounted for 78% of total energy supply, primarily from bioenergy, while fossil fuels dominated electricity generation. Hydropower potential remains underutilized, and solar resources are abundant but scarcely deployed. The profile underscores challenges in energy access, with per capita electricity generation among the lowest globally, and calls for diversification into solar, hydro, and modern bioenergy to improve energy security and resilience.

title: THE SOUTH SUDAN ENERGY ACCESS PROJECT (P178891)
source: South Sudan Ministry of Energy and Dams
description: The South Sudan Energy Access Project (P178891), supported by the World Bank, aims to expand reliable electricity access in one of the world’s least electrified countries. Implemented through the Ministry of Energy and Dams, the project focuses on off-grid solar solutions, mini-grids, and clean cooking technologies to reach households, schools, and health facilities. It also strengthens institutional capacity, private sector participation, and regulatory frameworks to ensure sustainability. By addressing affordability and infrastructure gaps, the project contributes to poverty reduction, climate resilience, and South Sudan’s long-term development goals.

title:
DRC NATIONAL 
ADAPTATION PLAN 
TO CLIMATE CHANGE 
(2022-2026)
source: Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC)  Ministry of the Environment and Sustainable Development
description: The DRC’s National Adaptation Plan (NAP) responds to the country’s high exposure to climate risks—floods, droughts, deforestation, and biodiversity loss—by promoting inclusive, sustainable, and climate-resilient development. It prioritizes adaptation in agriculture, water, health, energy, and infrastructure, with a strong emphasis on protecting ecosystems and vulnerable populations. The plan integrates gender equality and social inclusion, recognizing the disproportionate impacts of climate change on women and marginalized groups. Key components include institutional capacity building, climate data systems, early warning mechanisms, and community-based adaptation. The NAP aligns with the DRC’s national development strategies and international commitments under the UNFCCC and the Paris Agreement, aiming to mobilize climate finance and foster multisectoral collaboration for long-term resilience.

title: DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO COUNTRY CLIMATE AND DEVELOPMENT REPORT
description:
The Democratic Republic of Congo Country Climate and Development Report (2023) by the World Bank Group outlines how climate change intersects with DRC’s development challenges, and proposes integrated strategies for resilience, inclusive growth, and low-carbon transformation.
This comprehensive report highlights that DRC faces compounding risks: high poverty (62.3% in 2022), fragile institutions, and increasing climate extremes such as floods and droughts. Despite vast mineral wealth and hydropower potential, the country remains a net food importer and suffers from deforestation, poor infrastructure, and limited access to clean energy and water.
This report supports DRC’s 2030 National Strategic Development Plan and its ambition to become a middle-income country by 2035 through sustainable, diversified, and climate-resilient development.

title: Climate and Environmental Security in the Democratic Republic of Congo
description: The 2023 DGAP report “Climate and Environmental Security in the Democratic Republic of Congo” examines how climate change, environmental degradation, and resource exploitation intensify conflict and human insecurity in the DRC. It highlights how climate-induced disasters, deforestation, and competition over land and water exacerbate existing tensions, particularly in conflict-prone eastern regions. The report warns that global demand for critical minerals and conservation efforts may further marginalize local communities if not managed inclusively. It calls for integrated, community-centered approaches that align climate action with peacebuilding, human rights, and sustainable development.

title: Democratic Republic of the Congo: Climate, Peace and Security Fact Sheet
source: The Norwegian Institute of International Affairs
description: The Climate, Peace and Security Fact Sheet for the Democratic Republic of the Congo (2023), published by SIPRI and NUPI, highlights how climate change exacerbates conflict, displacement, and food insecurity. With over 25 million people facing acute hunger and 6.4 million displaced, climate shocks intensify competition over land, water, and resources. Armed groups exploit environmental assets, while weak governance and inequality hinder resilience. The report calls for conflict-sensitive climate adaptation, responsible resource extraction, and integrated peacebuilding strategies to address the complex links between climate and insecurity.

title: DRC’s Renewable Energy Potential and Country Overview
description: The DRC’s Renewable Energy Potential and Country Overview (2024) highlights the Democratic Republic of Congo’s vast untapped energy resources and opportunities for sustainable development. With immense hydropower potential—estimated to be among the largest globally—the report underscores the role of the Inga Dam and other renewable sources such as solar, wind, and biomass. Despite abundant resources, energy access remains limited, with rural electrification rates among the lowest in Africa. The overview calls for investment, policy reforms, and regional cooperation to harness renewables for inclusive growth, poverty reduction, and climate resilience.

title: DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE CONGO ENERGY PROFILE
description: The IRENA Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) Energy Profile (2025) highlights the country’s vast renewable energy potential alongside persistent access challenges. In 2022, renewables accounted for 96% of total electricity generation, primarily from hydropower, reflecting the DRC’s immense untapped capacity. Despite this, overall energy supply remains dominated by traditional biomass, which continues to fuel most household needs. The profile underscores low electrification rates, especially in rural areas, and calls for diversification into solar and modern bioenergy. Harnessing the DRC’s hydropower and renewable resources is critical to improving energy security, access, and sustainable development.

title: Somalia National Climate Change Policy
source: Somalia Ministry of Environment and Climate Change
description: Somalia’s National Climate Change Policy (2023) sets a framework for building climate resilience and promoting low-carbon development. It prioritizes adaptation in agriculture, water, health, and infrastructure, while supporting mitigation through renewable energy and sustainable land use. The policy emphasizes inclusive governance, gender equity, and climate finance, aligning with Somalia’s development goals and global climate commitments.

title: Climate Change Impact and Mitigation in Somalia: Water Harvesting and Conservation
description:
This report highlights how water harvesting and conservation can help Somalia mitigate climate change impacts and build resilience in drought-prone regions.
Titled “Climate Change Impact and Mitigation in Somalia: Water Harvesting and Conservation”, the publication explores how erratic rainfall, rising temperatures, and prolonged droughts threaten food security, pastoral livelihoods, and water access. It emphasizes the importance of rainwater harvesting, underground tanks, sand dams, and community-led watershed management to improve water availability and reduce vulnerability. The report also advocates for integrating traditional knowledge with modern techniques, strengthening institutional capacity, and scaling climate-smart water infrastructure to support sustainable development and peacebuilding in Somalia.

title: Examining the impact of climate change on water resources in Somalia: The role of adaptation
source: Abdimajid Ibrahim Ali, Youssef Kassem, Hüseyin Gökçekuş
description:
This study analyzes how climate change is reshaping water availability in Somalia and emphasizes the urgent need for adaptive strategies to safeguard livelihoods and ecosystems.
Titled “Examining the Impact of Climate Change on Water Resources in Somalia: The Role of Adaptation”, the paper explores how rising temperatures, erratic rainfall, and prolonged droughts are intensifying water scarcity across the country. It highlights the vulnerability of Somalia’s predominantly pastoral and agro-pastoral communities, whose dependence on seasonal water sources makes them especially susceptible to climate shocks. The authors advocate for integrated water resource management, community-based adaptation, and investment in water infrastructure—such as rainwater harvesting and small-scale irrigation—as critical tools for resilience. The study also calls for stronger institutional coordination, climate-informed planning, and inclusive policies that empower local actors to respond effectively to water-related climate risks.

title: Climate change, adaptation and building human resilience in Somalia
description:
This report explores how climate change is reshaping Somalia’s development landscape and outlines strategies to strengthen human resilience through inclusive, adaptive responses.
Titled “Climate Change, Adaptation and Building Human Resilience in Somalia” (2023), the publication highlights how rising temperatures, erratic rainfall, droughts, and floods are intensifying food insecurity, displacement, and poverty. It emphasizes the need for community-based adaptation, climate-smart agriculture, and water resource management, while also calling for stronger institutional coordination and integration of climate risks into national planning. The report advocates for empowering women, youth, and marginalized groups in climate decision-making and stresses the importance of linking humanitarian aid with long-term resilience strategies.

title: Impacts of Climate Change on Water Resource Availability in Somalia:  A Comprehensive Review
description:
This comprehensive review examines how climate change is reshaping water resource availability in Somalia and outlines key adaptation strategies to address growing scarcity.
The article “Impacts of Climate Change on Water Resource Availability in Somalia: A Comprehensive Review” explores how rising temperatures, erratic rainfall, and prolonged droughts are intensifying water stress across Somalia’s arid and semi-arid regions. It highlights the vulnerability of pastoral and agro-pastoral communities, whose livelihoods depend heavily on seasonal water sources. The review emphasizes the need for integrated water resource management,  rainwater harvesting, and climate-resilient infrastructure to mitigate risks. It also calls for stronger institutional coordination, investment in early warning systems, and community-based adaptation to enhance resilience and ensure sustainable water access.

title: Exploring climate change resilience of major crops in Somalia:implications for ensuring food security
source: Abdi, A. H., Sugow, M. O., & Halane, D. R.
description:
This study assesses the climate resilience of Somalia’s key crops and offers strategies to safeguard food security under worsening climate conditions.
Titled “Exploring Climate Change Resilience of Major Crops in Somalia: Implications for Ensuring Food Security” (2024), the article examines how rising temperatures, erratic rainfall, and droughts affect staple crops like sorghum, maize, and cowpeas. It evaluates crop performance under climate stress and identifies adaptive traits and practices that enhance resilience. The authors recommend promoting drought-tolerant varieties, improving seed systems, and scaling up climate-smart agriculture. Strengthening research, extension services, and farmer education is also emphasized to build long-term food system resilience in Somalia.

title:
Accelerating Sustainable and Clean Energy Access Transformation in Somalia (ASCENT) 
(P181341)
source: Somalia ministry of Energy and Resources
description: The Accelerating Sustainable and Clean Energy Access Transformation (ASCENT) Project (P181341), supported by the World Bank and the Ministry of Energy and Water Resources, aims to expand affordable, reliable, and sustainable energy access across Somalia. The project focuses on off-grid solar systems, mini-grids, and clean cooking solutions, targeting households, schools, health facilities, and businesses. It also strengthens institutional capacity, regulatory frameworks, and private sector participation to ensure long-term sustainability. By addressing energy poverty and climate resilience, ASCENT supports inclusive growth, poverty reduction, and Somalia’s transition toward a modern, renewable energy future.

title: SOMALIA ENERGY PROFILE
description: The IRENA Somalia Energy Profile (2025) provides an overview of the country’s energy landscape, marked by heavy reliance on traditional biomass and extremely limited electricity generation. In 2022, renewables accounted for over 90% of total energy supply, primarily from bioenergy, while modern renewable sources such as solar and wind remain underdeveloped despite abundant potential. Electricity generation is minimal, with access rates among the lowest globally, underscoring severe energy poverty. The profile highlights opportunities for scaling up decentralized solar, wind, and modern bioenergy to improve energy security, resilience, and inclusive development.
